sub_title: Communication Manager, Grant writer  &  Advocate for environmentally, socially, and economically healthy neighbourhoods.
summary:
Cultivating two socially responsible sustainable design organizations (Urban Habitat Chicago and Architecture for Humanity Toronto) provided me the opportunity to develop a range of administrative and community engagement skills, in addition to the presentation and design skills gained in my architecture career. 

__________________________________
ORGANIZATION LEADERSHIP	
Strategy and program development. Translating ideas into concrete plans. Finding project opportunities and resources. Chairing committee meetings.	Budgeting.	

PROGRAM, EVENT & PROJECT MANAGEMENT	
Planning, organisation, and time management skills. Coordinating teams, working collaboratively and independently.	Problem-solving. Organizing public education programs, design charettes. 
	
COMMUNICATION	
Native english speaking and promotional writing, french translation. Visual presentations, promotional and event marketing brochures and posters, website crafting, newsletter and email campaigns, social media presence.	
	
PEOPLE SKILLS
Motivating and recruiting volunteers, staff, board members, participants and partners.	Collaborating in varied cultural contexts.	

FUNDRAISING & DONOR DEVELOPMENT	
Writing winning grants and programs.  Fundraising events, obtaining online and in-kind donations. 
	
PERSONAL CHARACTERISTICS	
Proactive and persistent initiator. Willing and able to quickly learn new tools and methods.	Detail-oriented.

________________________________
AREAS OF EXPERTISE:
Environmentally sustainable urban design, landscaping, and urban farming. 
Urban food access and nutrition.
Design.

profile_positions.title: Jobseeker in Administration, Communications, Fundraising, Business Development

profile_positions.description:
President 2011-2012
Executive Director 2010-2011
Director of Communications 2008-2010

In close collaboration with founding members, including the current executive director, I developed and implemented a longer-term strategic plan for the existing organisation, substantially increased it's size, scope, reach, and funding through partnerships, new education programs, and new project sites, while targeting specific local social and environmental goals.  I provided a new organizational framework, including non-profit 501c3 status and major funding, to a very prolific organization with tremendous technical expertise. 
____________________________________________________________________________________
Urban Habitat Chicago (UHC) formed in 2004 to demonstrate the viability of sustainable concepts and practices in urban environments through research, education, and hands-on projects. 

UHC works at the intersections of urban agriculture, the built environment, materials reuse, and sustainable landscaping to create cycles of resources at all scales.  Projects include sustainable schoolyards, urban farms and gardens, social and physical site remediation, landscape materials research, classes and workshops for underprivileged youth, students and adults in sustainable environmental practices and urban agriculture.

http://www.urbanhabitatchicago.org/
profile_positions.title: Board President

company.name: Share Our Strength | No Kid Hungry

profile_positions.description:
As board member, I helped to define the local program's future during a period of re-evaluation and change of sponsoring home organisation. I also developed five school gardening and cooking programs (in collaboration with UHC) in high-poverty areas, for which I procured grants, other funding, and trained instructors. 

As a volunteer, I assisted in cooking and nutrition classes and taught fitness, to adults and youth facing food-insecurity. Through previous sponsor NNHS I assisted in stress management and budgeting classes for uninsured adults. I provided classroom and administrative support as well as recruiting expert volunteer staff for these programs. 

____________________________________________________________________________________
Share Our Strength’s Cooking Matters is a groundbreaking national nutrition education program that fights poverty and connects families with food by teaching families how to prepare healthy, tasty, low-cost meals.

The Cooking Matters program (formerly known as Operation Frontline) was previously run through the WIC (Women, Infants and Children) programs through the Chicago Near North Health Service Corporation, out of Komed-Holman Health Center in North Kenwood, Winfield Moody Health Center in Cabrini Green and other community centers throughout the city.

https://www.facebook.com/CookingMattersIllinois
https://cookingmatters.org/
profile_positions.title: Advisory Board Member & Cooking Matters Chicago Volunteer

profile_positions.description:
Six week residency teaching theater production - set and costume design - to 9th grade art students (age 14-18) at the Hyde Park Academy High school in south Chicago's challenged Woodlawn neighborhood.  
_____________________________________________________________________________________
The American Mosaic program was instigated by the American Theater company to engage high school students in underserved communities in theater and literature.

http://www.atcweb.org/american-mosaic
profile_positions.title: Set & Costume Design Teaching Resident at Hyde Park Academy Highschool (Woodlawn)

profile_positions.description:
Founded and led chapter part-time from March 2005. 
Managed full-time from December 2007 to July 2008.

Determined focus and direction of organization given volunteer and board interests and capacities. Created a volunteer base and attracted project participants, business partners, and attendees. Found resources primarily as in-kind donations of space, professional services, and materials. Developed well-attended lecture series for area design professionals, as well as small design projects. Led volunteers including the 10-member steering committee, as well as a large online community and public audience.

Architecture for Humanity Toronto (AFHTo) is a volunteer organization that promotes architectural and design solutions, as well as advocacy and public education to help build a sustainable and socially equitable living and working environment in Toronto, Ontario, Canada.

AFHTo is a wholly independent Canadian chapter of Architecture for Humanity International.

Members include architects, planners and designers, as well as activists, students, and concerned citizens, brought together by the common goal of transforming Toronto into a beautiful, livable and sustainable city.
